name: Spiroperone
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-4583
Reason: 1,1'-Spiro-2-benzopyran has a melting point of 106°C. The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of two additional phenyl rings and a methoxy group. Phenyl groups, when connected to a benzene ring, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. The methoxy group will also contribute to the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and van der Waals forces. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight. The methoxy group will also increase the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and van der Waals forces. The exact impact of the methoxy group is difficult to quantify without experimental data or detailed computational studies. However, we can estimate its effect as +20 degrees Celsius. The presence of two additional phenyl rings linked in a linear fashion will significantly augment the melting point. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight.
